results.title: Crystallization
results.creator_credit: Churchill Films, Dimension Films and Carroll Ballard
results.brief_description: The filming of magnified forms of crystals of common solutions as they are seen forming and then melting in polarized light captures the natural evolving shapes in a kaleidoscope of colour and in an infinite series of abstractions. Visually fascinating, all process were filmed at low magnification. Music by Phil Bishop, microphotography/crystalography by Robert R. Forrester and narration by Marguerite Ray. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Cry wolf
results.creator_credit: Damor Leaderfilm, Children's Film Foundation, Michael Truman and John Davis
results.brief_description: A young boy, Tony Walker (Anthony Kemp) has a habit of calling the police for crimes that don’t exist. Tony discovers that two men are planning to kidnap the Prime Minister - needless to say, no-one believes him. Finally Tony and his group of friends foil the efforts of the would-be kidnappers. Cast includes Ian Hendry, Wilfred Bramble, Maurice Kaufmann, Eileen Moore and Alfred Bell.

results.title: Cry the beloved country
results.creator_credit: British Lion Corporation, Lion Films and Zoltan Korda
results.brief_description: Based on the well-respected novel by South African author, Alan paton, “Cry the beloved country” is a film whose simplicity disguises the richness of its humanism. Two very different South Africans; one a wealthy white farmer, and the other a poor black priest, are united in the tragic deaths of their two sons. Despite the social and political realities of their country, the two extend a hand of friendship towards one another, and in that gesture raise the hope of peace and an end to the turmoil in South African society. Poitier, as a young preacher is excellent and Canada Lee gives a restrained but heartwarming performance.

results.title: Cry sweet revenge = Uncle Tom's cabin
results.creator_credit: Independent International Pictures, Kroger Babb and Géza von Radványi
results.brief_description: Uncle Tom, Sambo, Simon Legree: their names are American bywords and all are characters in this acclaimed film version of Harriet Beecher Stowe’s immortal classic of American literature. This shocking indictment of slavery in the American South, is based on the book Abraham Lincoln credited with starting the Civil War. It is an unforgettable presentation of the peace loving Tom, forced to submit to a sadistic master, the evil Simon Legree. The helpless slaves are raped, tortured, humiliated and eventually driven to rebel against their oppressors. “Uncle Tom’s Cabin” accurately depicts the attitudes of white 19th Century Americans towards the institution of slavery and dramatizes, in heart-breaking detail, the tragic breakup of black Kentucky families sold “down the river.” It is a brutal, passionate indictment of American slavery and the explosive racial hatred that spawned it. Starring John Kitzmiller, Herbert Lom, Olivia Moorefield, Mary Ann Jensen and Prentiss Moulden.

results.title: Cry of the wild
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Bill Brind and Bill Mason
results.brief_description: To hear Bill Mason tell about the making of this feature film (he is also the narrator) is to share with him his affection for his camera-quarry: the big northern timber wolves and pure-white Arctic wolves. What he brings to the screen is some unexcelled film footage and a great depth of lore about these wary, intelligent creatures of the Canadian wilds. Filming was done over three years in the Northwest Territories, British Columbia, the high Arctic, and near his Gatineau Hills (Quebec) home where he kept and observed three grown wolves and, eventually, the litter of cubs that provides some of the film’s most engaging sequences. Narration by Bill Mason.

results.title: Cry of the marsh
results.creator_credit: Bill Snyder Films and Bill Snyder
results.brief_description: Marshes are the breeding grounds of millions of water-birds and untold numbers of interrelated wildlife. These precious wetlands are being drained, victims of man’s relentless search for more farmland and urban space. The film captures the poetic beauty of marsh life, then the terror and awesome finality which results when man reclaims a marsh for his purposes.

results.title: Cry Havoc Mozambique
results.brief_description: Reviews the recent history of Mozambique, one of the last black African nations to gain independence. Documents South Africa’s systematic attempts to destabilise its independent, socialist neighbour. Since 1980 rebel bandits, trained and financed by South Africa have imposed a reign of terror and destruction on Mozambique, its people and culture, foreign aid workers and the country’s developing industries. Mozambique government spokesmen link peace to the end of apartheid in South Africa.

results.title: Cry from the heart: the stolen generation (A)
results.creator_credit: Gaia Films, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Jeni Kendell
results.brief_description: A confronting documentary which discusses the experiences of one Aboriginal family as a result of the Australian government’s policy in the first 70 years of the 20th Century of removing mixed Aboriginal children from their Aboriginal families and placing them in institutions or foster homes. The impact on thousands of Aboriginal families of being cut off from each other, their language and culture is evoked here in a very personal context. One family journey’s through the remembrance of the trauma of separation, confronting the consequences of it on their lives and the gradual process of being reunited and grieving for those family members they have lost. The progress of one family member is traced in detail from youth to time in jail to his release and his efforts to come to terms with his past and hopes for the future. Contains extensive interviews with family members, aboriginal support group leaders, and foster family members among others.
